N.C. Division of Coastal Management UNKNOWN SHORELINE_ESTUARINE_STRUCT_L vector digital data
SHORELINE_ESTUARINE_STRUCT_L
This file represents structure polyline features associated with the estuarine shoreline in North Carolina. Structure polyline features are based on 2006-2010 county level digital orthophotos from 6 inch and 2 foot resolution. Structure polyline features were generated from the imagery through heads up digitizing, and was digitized at a scale between 1:300 and 1:500 feet. Structure type is based on the presence of commercial, recreational and erosion control structures and attributed using guidance provided in a N.C. Division of Coastal Management generated methodology entitled "Charting the Estuarine Environment: A methodology spatially delineating a contiguous, estuarine shoreline of North Carolina."
The North Carolina Division of Coastal Management (DCM) has specific needs to establish a detailed estuarine shoreline (including the identification of shoreline related structures) for non-regulatory purposes that can serve as a basis for examining DCM's existing policy language within its estuarine and ocean system areas of environmental concern (AEC). This shapefile represents shoreline associated polyline structures (i.e. groins, bulkheads, sills, etc.) for that may be located along the land/water, vegetation/water or structure/water interfaces. This dataset was created to assist governmental agencies and others in making resource management decisions through the use of a Geographic Information System (GIS).

These data represent the location of polyline structures located along the estuarine shoreline in North Carolina based off of geo-rectified 2006-2010 aerial orthophotos. Therefore structures may or may not be current in their position and serves as a baseline for previously permitted structures. The N.C. Division of Coastal Management shall not be held liable for any errors in these data. This includes errors of omission, commission, errors concerning the content of the data, and relative and positional accuracy of the data. These data cannot be construed to be a legal document. Primary sources from which these data were compiled must be consulted for verification of information contained in the data.
N.C. Division of Coastal Management

GIS analysts check for consistency during the editing processes. Polyline structures are complete within North Carolina.
The boundaries were extracted from imagery or digitized based on the imagery consistent with standard GIS practices. Control is also provided by referencing quality standard orthophoto base maps during the mapping process.

Downloadable Data The North Carolina Estuarine Shoreline Mapping Project is a multiyear initiative designed to increase awareness of existing shoreline types and the prevalence of hardened structures along the North Carolina estuarine coastline. This effort will not result in the production of a complete hydrographic dataset for the coastal/estuarine environment. The final data set generated through the ESMP will not be used as a regulatory line and therefore may not be applicable to litigation entered into by the state or agencies within DENR. While efforts have been made to ensure that these data are accurate and reliable, DCM cannot assume liability for any damages, or misrepresentations, caused by any inaccuracies in the data, or as a result of the data to be used on a particular system. DCM makes no warranty, expressed or implied, nor does the fact of distribution constitute such a warranty. These data represented in an estuarine shoreline are believed to be logically consistent, though no tests were performed. All arcs will be snapped by the nodes to create consistently tied strings without node dangles and to ensure line geometry is topologically clean. While this shoreline dataset is dependent on aerial imagery taken for the 20 coastal counties prior to 2010, DCM understands that the position of the shoreline might change as the natural land changes or as better maps and more recent imagery become available.

East Carolina used the following catagories for structure type associated with linear structures. Boat Ramp: STRUC_TYPE = 11; Breakwater: STRUC_TYPE = 21; Groin/Jetty: STRUC_TYPE = 41; Sill: STRUC_TYPE = 61; Sloped Strucure: STRUC_TYPE = 71; Unknown: STRUC_TYPE = 81; Vertical Structure: STRUC_TYPE = 91. 20100428

Shoreline types captured by DCM's Estuarine Shoreline Mapping Project are broken down into the following categories. A brief explanation of each shoreline type follows its name. Explanations for the various shoreline types are taken from a DCM report by Geis and Bendell entitled, "Charting the Estuarine Environment: A mehthodology spatially deleneating a contiguous, estuarine shoreline of North Carolina."
Boat Ramp Vertical Structure
Boast ramps are concrete, brick, or asphalt structures sloping from high ground to below low water to allow vessels to be placed into the water. Instead of being represented by a polygon feature, these structures are digitized as a straight line at the structure/water interface.
Breakwater (STRUC_TYPE 21) A brekwater is a near shore or offshore, shore parallel, structure designed to reduce wave energy and trap sand. Breakwaters can be constructed from stone, riprap, concrete, or steel. Sediment can build up in the lee of the structure to the point that it is all high ground (above normal high water/normal water level).
Groin/Jetty (STRUC_TYPE 41) Groins and jettys are similar in appearance and are therefore represented in the same structure type category. A groin is a shore-perpendicular, typically straight, timber, rock, concrete, vinyl, or steel structure designed to trap sand on the updrift side. Groins can be constructed as either a single structure or in a series. A groin series will typically create a saw-toothed shaped shoreline. A jetty is a shore-perpendicular timber, rock, concrete, vinyl, or steel structure designed to direct a current, stabilize an inlet (small or large), prevent sediment from accumulating in a channel, or for accommodating vessels through an inlet. Jetties are longer than groins and are always associated with an inlet, canal, or basin entrance.
Sill (STRUC_TYPE 61) Sills are shore-parallel, nearshore, submerged structures built to reduce wave action on the adjacent shoreline. Sills can be constructed from timber or stone with the purpose of protecting or re-establishing marsh vegetation. Well established sills will look identical to a sloped structure (riprap revetment for marsh protection).
Sloped Structure (STRUC_TYPE 71) Any shore-parallel, watertight or porous structure designed to stabilize the shoreline and absorb wave energy with a sloped face. Riprap revetments or marsh enhancement riprap revetments are constructed from stone either along an existing sediment bank or waterward of an eroding wetland substrate.
Unknown (STRUC_TYPE 81) unknown structures represent any polyline structure unidentifiable from aerial photography, or that does not have an alternative STRUC_TYPE category (e.g. duck blinds).
Vertical Structure (STRUC_TYPE 91) Any shore-parallel, watertight structure (bulkheads or seawalls) used to stabilize the shoreline in a vertical manner. Bulkheads are designed to retain or prevent the sliding of the land by driven timber, vinyl, or steel. Seawalls are concrete or stacked/grouted rock structures set on or in the ground to prevent flooding or overtopping of the land. 2012071607213500FALSE20120620091928002012062009192800{87564CD3-0AE4-40BC-8C64-0DCA2EE05EF7}Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 3; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.1.4000SHORELINE_ESTUARINE_STRUCT_L2129566.4158233050200.5932521033300.21803935000.8137231-78.573371-75.42505336.5881133.7959221ISO 19115 Geographic Information - MetadataDIS_ESRI1.0dataset002file://Local Area Network4.399ShapefileNAD_1983_StatePlane_North_Carolina_FIPS_3200_Feet1623320120620
